label: Letter from Daniel of St. Thomas Jenifer to Unknown
description: Letter from Daniel of St. Thomas Jenifer to Unknown reporting the loss of a battle in Camden, South Carolina, Britain's efforts to attain allies in Europe, shortage of funds, and the arrival of an enemy fleet containing 2000 soldiers.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Daniel of St. Thomas Jenifer to Unknown reporting the loss of a battle in Camden, South Carolina, Britain's efforts to attain allies in Europe, shortage of funds, and the arrival of an enemy fleet containing 2000 soldiers.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
[Daniel of St. Thomas Jenifer to Unknown
May 22, 1781
[RvW Box 2 Folder 55; MSS. – A.L.S.]]
		
Phila. May 22d. 1781.
My dear Sir,
I see by the paper you were so kind as to inclose me
that the Tub is again thrown out to the Whale. Dissention is always the
mother of distress and if I mistake not we shall have enough of it before
Christmass [sic]. General Green[e]s not succeeding before Cambden will in
some measure dispirit our men, [and] perhaps prevent future confidence
and the British will be highly elated altho we did not lose more in
killed wounded [and] missing than 160 men [and] having taken near
three hundred at their different outPosts in SC including 50 taken by Col
Washington's Horse at Camden. General Green[e] informs Congress that
he should have gained a Compleat Victory had not two Companys of
the first Maryland Reg.t been thrown in to disorder wch occasioned Col
Gunby to change his Position, the second Reg.t conceiving this movement to be a retreat
followed, the confusion it occasioned obliged the General to order a Retreat
He lost neither Arms Ammunition or baggage, [and] says that it would make
no alteration in his plan his letter is dated the 27th of April but ‘tis said
the 30th. he was at Rugeleys Mill about 12 Miles from Camden.
No appearance of the arrival of the Second Division, I believe it is gone
to the West Indias [sic] [and] I suppose will not be with us till the Hurricanes
maybe expected. What is meant by this delay God knows, but I fear
some cursed mischief is hatching against us in Europe. Mr. Cumberland
was at Madrid so late as the 9th of March from thence he was to proceed
in a few days to Paris. little or no aid from the Court of Spain, some
promisses [sic] on certain Conditions.  The Minister has received important
dispatches from the Court of France by a Frigate arrived at Boston
He is soon to communicate part of their contents to Congress, but from
his delay I fear that they will not revive our Spirits much. Not a word
from Docr. Franklin which induces me to believe that he was not
apprized of her destination.
Mr. Morris has accepted of the Office of Finan
cier the principal part of his Plan is a Grand Bank. I am in great hopes of relief
from his ability [and] industry. You will I expect have the whole Scheme
sent from the Prest. of Congress to our assembly by next Post. All Paper
[End Page 1]
will I expect be called in, as every Emission, be the foundation [?]
good is immediately depreciated [and] the unwarry ruined by it. I 
fear that the late Fleet that sailed from New York is before this time
arrived in our Bay with 2000 Soldiers, as it was seen four days
ago off the Capes of Delaware. The Southern States I fear will be ruined
by piece Meals, if this happens [which God avert] the Northern [States] will soon
show the same fate.
What are your Delegates in Congress to do for Subsistence they
are without Money [and] will soon be without Credit. If the assembly or the
Council would order some wheat to be ground at the Head of the Bay
into superfine Flour it would command Hard Money [and] nothing
else will pass here but on the most ruinous terms. Mr. Joseph Gilpin
would undertake [and] execute this business with fidelity [and] dispatch. Col. [Colonel] Hollingsworth
has too much on his hands to allow him to pay proper attention to this
supply.
Present me to your Lady [and] believe me as ever
Your affectionate friend.
Dan of St. Thos Jenifer [Daniel of St. Thomas Jenifer]
[P.S.]
General Washington left Head Quarters on Saturday
to meet the Count de Rochambeau to settle the plan of operation 
for this Campaign
Remember me to our late Governor
[End Page 2]
